Pitfall of GCDAsyncSokcet

Jan 9, 2014
3 minute read

I use CocoaAsyncSocket, a 3rd lib that encapsulates the CFNetwork in iOS, to achieve data transmission via TCP/IP protocol. The introduction and usage of this library is here.

According to the documentation, the class that has achieved the GCDAsyncSocketDelegate is mandatory. Then I use singleton to decouple the view controller and command sender like this:

 1 #import <Foundation/Foundation.h>
 2 #import "GCDAsyncSocket.h"
 3 
 4 @interface CommandSender : NSObject <GCDAsyncSocketDelegate>
 5 
 6 + (CommandSender *)sharedSender;
 7 
 8 - (void)writeDataTest;
 9 
10 @end
 1 #import "CommandSender.h"
 2 
 3 #define LOCAL_IP_ADDRESS @"127.0.0.1"
 4 #define PORT 4000
 5 
 6 @interface CommandSender () {
 7     GCDAsyncSocket *asyncSocket;
 8 }
 9 
10 @end
11 
12 @implementation CommandSender
13 
14 // Singleton
15 + (CommandSender *)sharedSender
16 {
17     static dispatch_once_t onceToken;
18     __strong static id _sharedSender = nil;
19     dispatch_once(&onceToken, ^{
20         _sharedSender = [[CommandSender alloc] initWithConnection];
21     });
22     return _sharedSender;
23 }
24 
25 - (id)initWithConnection
26 {
27     if (self = [super init]) {
28         // Initialize the GCDAsyncSocket
29         asyncSocket = [[GCDAsyncSocket alloc] initWithDelegate:self
30                                                  delegateQueue:dispatch_get_main_queue()];
31     }
32 
33     // Build connection with server
34     NSError *err = nil;
35     if (![asyncSocket connectToHost:LOCAL_IP_ADDRESS
36                              onPort:PORT
37                         withTimeout:10
38                               error:&err]) {
39         NSLog(@"Connection error %@", err);
40     }
41 
42     return self;
43 }
44 
45 // Test function of sending message
46 - (void)writeDataTest
47 {
48     [asyncSocket writeData:[@"Well, server is waiting for you." dataUsingEncoding:NSASCIIStringEncoding]
49                withTimeout:-1
50                        tag:888];
51 }
52 
53 #pragma mark - delegate
54 
55 // Callback function when connecting successfully
56 - (void)socket:(GCDAsyncSocket *)sock didConnectToHost:(NSString *)host port:(uint16_t)port
57 {
58     NSLog(@"Connecting successfully. Host is %@, port is %d", host, port);
59 }
60 
61 // Callback function when sending data successfully
62 - (void)socket:(GCDAsyncSocket *)sock didWriteDataWithTag:(long)tag
63 {
64     NSLog(@"Writing data successfully, Tag = %ld", tag);
65 }

I test it in AppDelegate like this:

1 [[CommandSender sharedSender] writeDataTest];

There is no any logging messages neither failed nor succeed. Then I try to invoke the test function in view controller, problem solved. The singleton is out of work because the AppDelegate was released early, causing the socket to be released early as well. This should be the basic knowledge of GCD, but still need to be taken into account.

Don’t be a victim.

3rd-lib GCD iOS objective-c socket
